issue.title: How to query if robot is initialized

content.raw: I don't think there's a good way yet. Would it be useful if this information came through a ROS topic? It will also be needed after detaching from the harness when skipping checkpoints or restarting a checkpoint.
content.html: I don't think there's a good way yet. Would it be useful if this information came through a ROS topic? It will also be needed after detaching from the harness when skipping checkpoints or restarting a checkpoint.

issue.title: How to query if robot is initialized

content.raw: a latched topic might serve the purpose, we are subscribing to `/valkyrie/harness/detach` for development purposes, but that message disappears after 3 seconds.
content.html: a latched topic might serve the purpose, we are subscribing to /valkyrie/harness/detach for development purposes, but that message disappears after 3 seconds.

issue.title: How to query if robot is initialized

content.raw:
Adding this here because it's a related topic. 

Information is needed after a restart to tell the robot the current task and checkpoint, and that a restart occurred. Might even need information about pose. 

The current competition software doesn't update task and checkpoint until the start service call is made. That service call has to match the current task and checkpoint which is unknown on a restart. Also, if a competitor decides to do each task separately their software needs to know the task and checkpoint they are starting. That's not as big an issue since if I'm starting task 2 presumably I know that and can send the right start. 

It would be useful if there were a generic start message. Use task number 99. That would start task reporting and the robot would know the task and checkpoint that are in progress. 

Incidentally, to the point of the question above. My software waits for the simulated time to exceed 27 seconds before proceeding. It's worked for the qualification runs and works now. It'll be interesting to see if it works in the competition environment.

This is related to Issue #151 not having any task information even though the start command was given. IMO the task and checkpoint state should always be available to the robot. I fixed my issue specific to $151 but feel the restart situations causes a similar condition.
content.html:
Adding this here because it's a related topic.

Information is needed after a restart to tell the robot the current task and checkpoint, and that a restart occurred. Might even need information about pose.

The current competition software doesn't update task and checkpoint until the start service call is made. That service call has to match the current task and checkpoint which is unknown on a restart. Also, if a competitor decides to do each task separately their software needs to know the task and checkpoint they are starting. That's not as big an issue since if I'm starting task 2 presumably I know that and can send the right start.

It would be useful if there were a generic start message. Use task number 99. That would start task reporting and the robot would know the task and checkpoint that are in progress.

Incidentally, to the point of the question above. My software waits for the simulated time to exceed 27 seconds before proceeding. It's worked for the qualification runs and works now. It'll be interesting to see if it works in the competition environment.

This is related to Issue #151 not having any task information even though the start command was given. IMO the task and checkpoint state should always be available to the robot. I fixed my issue specific to $151 but feel the restart situations causes a similar condition.

issue.title: How to query if robot is initialized

content.raw: Another thought is to return the current task and checkpoint from the start task service call.
content.html: Another thought is to return the current task and checkpoint from the start task service call.

issue.title: How to query if robot is initialized

content.raw: A competitor can opt to run each task in separate runs. Running through Task 1 there is no report that checkpoint 4 is completed. This leaves the competitors software uncertain if the final checkpoint for the task is completed if the separate task run option is followed.
content.html: A competitor can opt to run each task in separate runs. Running through Task 1 there is no report that checkpoint 4 is completed. This leaves the competitors software uncertain if the final checkpoint for the task is completed if the separate task run option is followed.

issue.title: How to query if robot is initialized

content.raw: The competition will not trigger skips or restarts on its own, teams should be able to know what checkpoint they asked to skip to.
content.html: The competition will not trigger skips or restarts on its own, teams should be able to know what checkpoint they asked to skip to.

issue.title: How to query if robot is initialized

content.raw: You ignore the issue of knowing whether the final checkpoint in a task has completed when doing the competition task by task. Also, still ignoring the restart situation where knowing the current task is difficult.
content.html: You ignore the issue of knowing whether the final checkpoint in a task has completed when doing the competition task by task. Also, still ignoring the restart situation where knowing the current task is difficult.

issue.title: How to query if robot is initialized

content.raw:
> You ignore the issue of knowing whether the final checkpoint in a task has completed when doing the competition task by task.

I agree this is an issue, we ran into the same thing when implementing scoring, I'll take a look.

> Also, still ignoring the restart situation where knowing the current task is difficult.

* The restart service which will be provided restarts the current checkpoint. 
* It isn't possible to go back to a previous checkpoint
* When skipping to a checkpoint ahead, teams need to name which checkpoint they want. 
* While restarting/skipping, the usual task message will still be published, and time will still be counting down.

I'm currently implementing a new publisher which will publish harness status so teams know when Val has been lowered and is ready to be controlled.
content.html:
You ignore the issue of knowing whether the final checkpoint in a task has completed when doing the competition task by task.

I agree this is an issue, we ran into the same thing when implementing scoring, I'll take a look.

Also, still ignoring the restart situation where knowing the current task is difficult.

  • The restart service which will be provided restarts the current checkpoint.
  • It isn't possible to go back to a previous checkpoint
  • When skipping to a checkpoint ahead, teams need to name which checkpoint they want.
  • While restarting/skipping, the usual task message will still be published, and time will still be counting down.

I'm currently implementing a new publisher which will publish harness status so teams know when Val has been lowered and is ready to be controlled.

issue.title: How to query if robot is initialized

content.html:
Pull request #79 adds a new message which publishes the harness state on /srcsim/finals/harness and will be available during the finals. Teams can use it to know when the harness has been completely detached.

@rmerriam , that pull request also makes it so the task message is also published while the robot is in the start box, in which case the checkpoint number in the message is 0. The moment the last checkpoint of a task is completed, one last message is published which has finished == true and the checkpoint number is <total CP> + 1.

Worth mentioning that on pull request #69 a score message is being published, and that contains the results for all previous checkpoints, including from previous tasks. That's another way to know where you currently are at.

issue.title: How to query if robot is initialized

content.raw: The harness topic and message have been merged, I updated the [skipping](#!/osrf/srcsim/wiki/skip_summary) tutorial and the [API](#!/osrf/srcsim/wiki/api) docs
content.html: The harness topic and message have been merged, I updated the skipping tutorial and the API docs
